column7: The Mint's topics are Business ethics and values, Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing, Cybersecurity, data and privacy, Health, safety and well-being, Responsible sourcing, and Air Quality and Gases.

column13: The Mint adopts a continuous improvement approach to this vital aspect of our business. The Mint is implementing Phase 2 of our AML Remediation Program, which has three interdependent components: Customer Data Remediation Project, Customer Process Uplift Project, and Customer Lifecycle Technology and Data Project.\t

Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
column13: When due, obligations for contributions to defined contribution plans are recognised as personnel expenses in the consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income. Prepaid contributions are recognised as assets to the extent that a cash refund or reduction in future payments is available.
column20: Defined contribution plans, Personnel expenses, Prepaid contributions, Asset recognition

column6: Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
column7: The Mint also intends to provide equal opportunities and rewards to all our employees, regardless of gender, disability or cultural background. The gender pay gap is an area of focus, with the gap between our male and female employees ' pay improving this year to 12.2%

column6: Proportion of senior management hired from the local community
column7: The Mint is increasing the proportion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in our workforce from 2% to 4% by 2025.

column13: The Mint installed new Pyrometallurgical Advanced Melting (PAM) units, which enable gold to be refined with significantly reduced use of potentially harmful gases. Since the units were brought online, reductions in gas input have already been achieved. It will increase as they are progressively ramped up to total capacity over the coming year.
column20: Pyrometallurgical Advanced Melting (PAM) units, Gold refining, Environmental impact

column13: The Business Technology team worked to strengthen its role in supporting functions across the business in 2022-23. A vital part of this work was a complete refresh of our network infrastructure to improve connections to information technology in previously inaccessible areas. It has enhanced the capacity of refinery and coining division employees to use IT services to connect to critical equipment, improving efficiency and enabling data-driven decision-making.
column20: Business Technology, Network infrastructure, IT support

column13: The Mint's business Technology team works with external specialists to audit our cybersecurity infrastructure regularly. The Mint has reshaped the scope of these tests against the backdrop of significant cybersecurity events in Australia in 2022-23. The Mint completed a comprehensive technical test of our security infrastructure early in 2023.
column20: Cybersecurity infrastructure, Cyber resilience, Continuous improvement

column13: Risk assessments were conducted to determine critical risks and critical controls. These assessments were peer-reviewed, validated, and endorsed by senior management. Work also commenced developing critical control observations, which will form a key part of the monitoring and verification process.
column20: Risk assessments, Critical risks, Critical controls

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: The anti-bribery and corruption policy establishes our commitment to opposing all forms of bribery and corruption and provides appropriate limits on giving and receiving donations and gifts. In FY 2022-23, the Mint updated its Anti-bribery and corruption policy to strengthen our zero-tolerance approach to all forms of bribery and corruption, including examples of behaviour by Mint employees that would not be tolerated.
column20: Anti-bribery and corruption policy, Zero-tolerance approach, Bribery prevention

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: In FY 2022-23, the Mint updated our Anti-bribery and corruption policy to strengthen the zero-tolerance approach to all forms of bribery and corruption, including examples of behaviour by Mint employees that would not be tolerated. The revised policy is now approved and in use.
column20: Zero-tolerance Approach, Anti-bribery and corruption policy, Policy update

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices

column7: Income tax is recognised in the consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income except to the extent that it relates to items recognised directly in equity, in which case it is recognised in equity. Current tax is the expected tax payable on the taxable income for the year adjusted by changes in deferred tax assets and liabilities, using tax rates enacted at the reporting date and any adjustment to tax payable in respect of previous years.

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: The Board's policy is to maintain an adequate capital base to sustain the business's future development. The consolidated entity's target was to achieve a return on equity of 12.0% before the Income Tax equivalent. During the year ended 30 June 2023, the return was 24.5% (2022 23.0%).
column20: Capital Risk Management, Board policy, Capital base maintenance

column13: The Mint has previously reported that legacy operations at the refinery resulted in the historical contamination of groundwater. In 2022-23, the Mint continued progressing a remediation action plan in line with our obligations under airport legislation and other relevant laws. Key stakeholders are kept informed on progress.
column20: Groundwater Remediation, Historical contamination, Environmental compliance

column13: The Mint's ISO 14001-accredited Environmental Management Plan drives our approach by managing three key wastewater streams: industrial process water, Collected surface water (site runoff), and Abstracted groundwater.
